properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Persistent snow squalls are expected. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Snow squalls with total amounts of 20 to 40 cm is expected. Locations: Northern mainland Nova Scotia, Cape Breton Highlands and eastern Prince Edward Island. Time span: This afternoon to Saturday evening. Remarks: A cold northerly flow and strong winds will lead to the development of snow squalls starting this afternoon. Accumulations will vary with the intensity of the snow squalls with the highest amounts expected over the Cape Breton Highlands. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snow squall warnings are issued when bands of snow form that produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-30T06:36:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-29T14:37:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3067642819.2019
Area: Pictou County, Antigonish County, Inverness County - south of Mabou, Inverness County - Mabou and north, Victoria County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong, potentially damaging winds will gust to 90 kilometres per hour beginning overnight tonight and continuing into Sunday morning. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-30T08:51:28-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-29T16:52:28-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0667438683.2019
Area: Blanc-Sablon
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant amounts of precipitation are expected. Total snowfall: near 10 cm inland and over higher terrain. Total rainfall: 20 to 40 mm along the coast. Locations: Burgeo area to the Connaigre Peninsula. Time span: continuing until this afternoon for the Connaigre Peninsula and until Saturday evening over the Burgeo highway. Remarks: Precipitation will gradually taper off on Saturday. Motorists are advised to be prepared for winter driving conditions over inland areas. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-30T06:38:08-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-29T14:39:08-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0026524668.2019
Area: Connaigre, Burgeo - Ramea
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant high-elevation snowfall and coastal rainfall will continue. Total snowfall: 30 to 50 cm over the Long Range Mountains. Much less along the coast. Total rainfall: 20 to 30 mm along the coast. Locations: western and northern Newfoundland. Time span: continuing until Sunday morning. Remarks: Accumulations will vary considerably, with the largest totals occurring over the highest elevations of the Long Range Mountains. Anyone planning travel across higher parts of the Trans Canada Highway, Viking Trail or Roddickton Highway should expect winter driving conditions. Users of backcountry trails should be prepared for large amounts of snowfall. Conditions may deteriorate suddenly over short distances. ### Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-30T11:29:15-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-29T19:30:15-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1168351692.2019
Area: Corner Brook and vicinity, Gros Morne, Bay St. George, Northern Peninsula East, Parson's Pond - Hawke's Bay, Port Saunders and the Straits
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Flurries at times heavy are expected. Snow squalls are likely as a cold northerly flow develops over the Gulf of St. Lawrence. Total snowfall: locally up to 20 cm by Saturday afternoon. Locations: Northern mainland Nova Scotia and western Prince Edward Island. Time span: This afternoon until Saturday evening. Remarks: Flurries at times heavy will develop this afternoon and will persist tonight and Saturday. Snow squalls with locally poor visibility are likely as well. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A wintry mix of precipitation continues. Snowfall today into tonight: 10 to 15 cm. Rainfall early Saturday: 5 to 10 mm. Additional snowfall Saturday afternoon and evening: 2 to 4 cm, except 10 cm over higher terrain. Remarks: Snow, at times heavy, will continue today and then mix with rain or drizzle tonight. Precipitation will transition back to all snow again by Saturday afternoon. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-30T06:38:58-00:00

Area: Buchans and the interior
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Accumulating snow inland today. Significant rainfall along the coast today, tonight and Saturday. Total snowfall: 5 to 10 cm inland. Total rainfall: 25 to 40 mm. Locations: northeast coast of Newfoundland. Time span: this morning until Saturday afternoon. Remarks: Snow inland and rain along the coast will continue today before changing to showers or drizzle later today or early tonight. Rain will then continue into Saturday. Snowfall accumulations will be variable, with the highest accumulations likely occurring inland and over elevated terrain. Motorists are advised to be prepared for winter driving conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-30T06:41:45-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-29T14:42:45-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3606719368.2019

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Dense fog is occurring in areas of southern Alberta. The fog is particularly dense south of Nanton along highway 2 to the Canada-USA border and east of Lethbridge towards Medicine Hat. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Fog advisories are issued when near zero visibilities in fog are expected or occurring. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong northerly winds expected tonight through Saturday night. Maximum gusts: 100 to 110 km/h. Location: Hawke's Bay to Port Aux Basques. Time span: beginning early this evening and continuing until roughly midnight on Saturday night. Remarks: Maximum gusts are expected mainly along coastal areas exposed to the north or northwest. Winds should begin to diminish after midnight on Saturday night. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-30T11:31:23-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-29T19:32:23-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4190595147.2019
Area: Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity, Corner Brook and vicinity, Gros Morne, Bay St. George, Parson's Pond - Hawke's Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A wintry mix of precipitation is expected. Total snowfall: 10 to 20 cm over higher elevations. Total rainfall: 10 to 20 mm over lower elevations. Locations: Deer Lake and the Humber Valley area. Time span: continuing until Saturday evening. Remarks: A mixture of snow and rain will today and persist through Saturday. Lower areas in the valley will receive mainly rain with just a couple centimetres of snow. Adjacent higher terrain, however, will receive mainly snow with potential for significant accumulations. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-30T06:43:55-00:00

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong northerly winds expected overnight tonight and again Saturday night. Maximum gusts: near 100 km/h. Location: The Great Northern Peninsula. Time span: From midnight until early morning of both tonight and Saturday night. Remarks: Maximum gusts are expected mainly along coastal areas exposed to the north or northwest. Winds during the day on Saturday will remain strong, with gusts likely near 80 km/h. Winds will begin to diminish on Sunday morning. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Brief blizzard conditions are possible early this afternoon for Ulukhaktok. However, the most likely area for these conditions to occur is now forecast to be south of the community over the Amundsen Gulf. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A mixture of significant wintry precipitation will continue. Total snowfall: 5 to 10 cm, except 20 to 30 cm inland and over higher terrain. Total rainfall: 20 to 30 mm along the coast and over lower elevation areas of the Humber Valley. Locations: Higher elevation areas of route 430 and the Baie Verte Peninsula. Time span: continuing until Saturday evening. Remarks: Snow and rain will continue tonight and Saturday. Snowfall accumulations will be highly variable, with the highest totals occurring inland and over higher elevations. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-30T12:41:53-00:00

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall: 25 to 40 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 110 km/h. Locations: Rigolet to Black Tickle. Time span: tonight until Sunday afternoon. Remarks: A mixture of rain and snow will transition to snow at times heavy tonight and persist into Sunday. Strong northerly winds will develop Saturday afternoon and ease Sunday afternoon. The combination of snowfall and strong winds will cause blowing snow, especially over exposed areas. ### Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-30T11:53:25-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-29T19:54:25-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1650562278.2019
Area: Cartwright to Black Tickle, Rigolet and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Large waves, pounding surf and elevated water levels are expected. Wave heights: 3 to 7 metres. Locations: North facing shorelines of The Gulf of St. Lawrence, Northumberland Strait and Cabot Strait. Time span: Tonight, Saturday, then subsiding on Sunday. Remarks: The highest waves will be at north facing shorelines of the Magdalen Islands, Prince Edward Island and Cape Breton where waves of 5 to 7 metres and water levels of near a metre above normal are expected. Over north facing shorelines of New Brunswick and mainland Nova Scotia, wave heights are expected to be in the 3 to 4 metre range with a water level of 50 cm to 1 metre above normal. Shore or beach erosion and damage to coastal infrastructure is possible in vulnerable areas. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-30T11:25:38-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-29T19:26:38-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1978793763.2019
Area: Îles-de-la-Madeleine
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Freezing Drizzle Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Areas of freezing drizzle are expected or occurring. Freezing drizzle has been occurring at Brandon since the overnight hours, and is likely also occurring throughout much of southwestern Manitoba. Conditions will continue to be favourable for freezing drizzle through the night tonight and early Saturday morning, after which time drier air should end most of the precipitation. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and hazardous. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-30T10:32:08-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-29T18:33:08-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4254803447.2019

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Very strong southwest winds tonight in Cape Dorset. Strong west to southwest winds continue at Cape Dorset late this afternoon. The strongest winds, southwest as high as 70 gusting 100 km/h are expected tonight. An approaching low pressure trough will bring lighter winds late overnight and for Saturday. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall is expected over some areas. Total snowfall: 5 to 10 cm except near 20 cm inland and over higher terrain. Locations: Norman Bay to Lodge Bay. Time span: tonight until Saturday night. Remarks: A mixture of rain and snow will transition to snow at times heavy tonight and persist into Saturday night. ### Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-30T11:55:02-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-29T19:56:02-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2499769406.2019
Area: Norman Bay to Lodge Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected, with accumulating snowfall. Maximum gusts: 90 km/h, except 110 along parts of the coast beginning Saturday until Sunday. Total snowfall: 15 to 30 cm continuing until Sunday morning. Locations: Hopedale and vicinity. Remarks: Snow will continue tonight through Saturday. Strong northerly winds will develop on Saturday. The combination of snowfall and strong winds will cause blowing snow, especially over exposed areas. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-30T11:51:54-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-29T19:52:54-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1168061542.2019
Area: Hopedale and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Accumulating snow will continue. Total snowfall: 10 to 15 cm except near 30 cm over higher terrain. Locations: Upper Lake Melville and Eagle River. Time span: continuing until Sunday morning. Remarks: Snow accumulations will vary considerably, with the largest totals occurring over the highest elevations. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate. Motorists should be prepared for winter driving conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-30T11:51:08-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-29T19:52:08-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2104977264.2019
Area: Upper Lake Melville, Eagle River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and strong winds continuing through Sunday. Total snowfall: 30 to 50 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 110 km/h. Locations: Postville and Makkovik. Time span: continuing until Sunday afternoon. Remarks: Snow will continue tonight and become heavy at times again on Saturday. The snow is expected to persist into Sunday. Strong northerly winds will develop Saturday afternoon and ease Sunday afternoon. The combination of snowfall and strong winds will cause blowing snow, especially over exposed areas. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-30T11:52:40-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-29T19:53:40-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3299023658.2019
Area: Postville - Makkovik
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Large waves, pounding surf and elevated water levels are expected. Wave heights: 3 to 7 metres. Locations: North facing shorelines of The Gulf of St. Lawrence, Northumberland Strait and Cabot Strait. Time span: Tonight, Saturday, then subsiding on Sunday. Remarks: The highest waves will be at north facing shorelines of the Magdalen Islands, Prince Edward Island and Cape Breton where waves of 5 to 7 metres and water levels of near a metre above normal are expected. Over north facing shorelines of New Brunswick and mainland Nova Scotia, wave heights are expected to be in the 3 to 4 metre range with a water level of 50 cm to 1 metre above normal. Shore or beach erosion and damage to coastal infrastructure is possible in vulnerable areas. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-30T11:25:38-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-29T19:26:38-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1223966534.2019
Area: Kings County P.E.I., Queens County P.E.I., Prince County P.E.I.
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Southwesterly winds will reach up to 100 km/h beginning overnight tonight. These winds will diminish Saturday afternoon. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
